thread.title: Cocaine challenge is the dumbest, most dangerous social media challenge ever
thread.title_full: Cocaine challenge is the dumbest, most dangerous social media challenge ever - San Antonio Express-News

author: Camilo Smith, Chron.com
title: Cocaine challenge is the dumbest, most dangerous social media challenge ever
text:
Image 1 of / 74 74 The new viral video challenge? Mexican women doing coke: http://www.dazeddigital.com/artsandculture/article/26666/1/the-new-viral-video-challenge-mexican-women-doing-coke … #retodelpasesito
The new viral video challenge? Mexican women doing coke:... Image 2 of 74 Los mirreyes which is a take on "mi rey" or "my king" is a term that started to see life on social media some time around 2011. It replaced previous terms for Mexico's rich elite kids, such as "juniors" or "fresas".
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com Los mirreyes which is a take on "mi rey" or "my king" is a term... Image 3 of 74 Los mirreyes is considered one of the first "youth identities" to emerge in the 21st Century.
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com Los mirreyes is considered one of the first "youth identities" to... Image 4 of 74 Los mirreyes is considered a youth identity that rejects México Profundo "the Mexico to which most Mexican's belong."
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com Los mirreyes is considered a youth identity that rejects México... Image 5 of 74 The youth subculture of los mirreyes has become increasingly visible due to posting of the lavish life on Tumblr, Instagram and Twitter.
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com The youth subculture of los mirreyes has become increasingly... Image 6 of 74 "Lobukis" is a term used for some females in the los mirreyes subculture, and they're often subjected to put downs.
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com "Lobukis" is a term used for some females in the los mirreyes... Image 7 of 74 Rich, partying students who attend elite Mexican universities such as Universidad Iberoamericana and Tec de Monterrey generally fit the profile of los mirreyes.
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com Rich, partying students who attend elite Mexican universities such... Image 8 of 74 The duckface is almost a prerequisite look in los mirreyes photos.
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com The duckface is almost a prerequisite look in los mirreyes photos. Image 9 of 74 Just looking like a mirrey has become akin to having class in Mexico.
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com Just looking like a mirrey has become akin to having class in Mexico. Image 10 of 74 Mirreyes like to take photos that show exotic cars, watches and partying on yachts.
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com Mirreyes like to take photos that show exotic cars, watches and... Image 11 of 74 "Mirreye" has become such a mainstream term that some people mock it.
Photo: Instagram.com/cars_vaqueiro "Mirreye" has become such a mainstream term that some people mock it. Image 12 of 74 Before los mirreyes, Mexican youth subcultures were made up of marginalized groups.
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com Before los mirreyes, Mexican youth subcultures were made up of... Image 13 of 74 The term "luismiguelear" is a mirreyes term meaning to live the life like entertainers Luis Miguel, Jaime Camil or Roberto Palazuelos. That is, always sun-tanned playboys.
Photo: Instagram The term "luismiguelear" is a mirreyes term meaning to live the... Image 14 of 74 Private jet rides are another stereotype of the mirreye life.
Photo: Twitter.com/mirrreybook Private jet rides are another stereotype of the mirreye life. Image 15 of 74 The style of los mirreyes includes designer clothing, usually Polo shirts and on occassion, the need to expose the bare chest when wearing a button down.
Photo: Twitter.com/mirrreybook The style of los mirreyes includes designer clothing, usually Polo... Image 16 of 74 Those who might be qualified to fit the mirrey mold come from places near Mexico City like Tecamachalco, Lomas de Chapultepec, Bosques de las Lomas, Polanco, Zona Esmeralda, Jardines de la Montaña, Pedregal de San Angel y en Santa Fe and other locations where homes cost dollars and fetch over $1 million.
Photo: Https://twitter.com/mirrreybook Those who might be qualified to fit the mirrey mold come from... Image 17 of 74 According to a 2012 study, mirreyes are happy to rely on their family fortunes. While they hide family dysfunction (alcoholism, adultery), they connect with their elders over chats about vacations and other superficial matters.
Photo: Https://twitter.com/mirrreybook According to a 2012 study, mirreyes are happy to rely on their... Image 18 of 74 Although most of the mirreyes are raised Catholic, they are generally not into helping society or the poor, but in partying and getting wasted, also known as "el desmadre."
Photo: Https://twitter.com/mirrreybook Although most of the mirreyes are raised Catholic, they are... Image 19 of 74 The life of los mirreyes is described as being perpetually on summer vacation.
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com The life of los mirreyes is described as being perpetually on... Image 20 of 74 Los mirreyes live the fast life in fancy cars and fashion labes like Gucci, Hermes, D&C, Burberry, Moschino, AX, Lacoste, and Prada among others.
Photo: Mirrreybook.tumblr.com Los mirreyes live the fast life in fancy cars and fashion labes... Image 21 of 74 Mirreyes are considered part of a post-modern, narcissistic, "me" generation that has arrived in Mexico.

Photo: Theworldsbestever.com Source: theworldsbestever.com Image 74 of 74 Cocaine challenge is the dumbest, most dangerous social media challenge ever 1 / 74 Back to Gallery As far as social media challenges go, this is one of the most dangerous to come along in a while. Young cocaine sniffers in Mexico are being blamed for starting the trend. It requires people to video record or simply snap a photo of themselves inhaling the narcotic and challenging a friend to do the same.
Know as the #retodelpasesito or “Little pass challenge” it’s an excuse to abuse a drug that’s no doubt a lucrative source of income for Mexico’s drug traffickers. As much as the trend is gaining steam for those dumb enough to share their drug use with the world, there have been plenty of warnings about the danger, or “peligro” associated with the use of cocaine.
But not everyone is on board with this one as a Change.org petition was started recently to dissuade people form abusing the drug in the name of a social media challenge. Instead, the petition which calls the abuse of chemical drugs a form of suicide, tells people to consider the ice bucket challenge from which the cocaine version is based, instead.
